answers.author: Michael Van Milligen
answers.text:
The City of Dubuque has an agreement with the Greater Dubuque Development Corporation (www.greaterdubuque.org), a private not-for-profit, to provide funding mostly on the basis of specific tasks. The City of Dubuque has 5 seats on their Board of Directors and particpates in developing their strategic plan (this is done every 5 years) which has specific targets around job creation, workforce development, wage levels and community development. GDDC has a $1.8 million annual budget and 9 staff members with the city and county providing 1/3 of the funding and the business community providing the other 2/3's. The city also has an economic development department with 4 employees and an over $500,000 operational budget. I will send you a copy of the funding agreement and the GDDC Annual Report. We have gone from 38,000 people working in Dubuque County (poulation 95,000) 30 years ago when GDDC was formed to over 60,00 working here today and from one of the highest unemployment rates in the country at that time to one that is much lower than the national average today.

answers.author: Toby Cotter
answers.text:
The City provides annual financial support to the non-profit Economic Development Corporation in the City on an annual basis as part of the budgeting process. It is tied to needs and anticipated outcomes.

author: Margie Rose
text: My community is trying to understand how communities fund their Economic Development Corporations.  If your community provides funding to your Economic Development Corporation, how is the funding determined?  Is it based on population or something similar? Your response is greatly appreciated.
title: Economic Development Corporation Funding
